data.title: Power point 98: Review and tutorial
data.meta_description: Explore millions of resources from scholarly journals, books, newspapers, videos and more, on the ProQuest Platform.
data.text:
FOR AT LEAST a decade, I have used a wide variety of presentation and authoring software, including just about every version of HyperCard, m-Power, Digital Chisel, Astound, SuperCard, Power Point, Persuasion, HyperStudio, Linkway, Director, and Apple Media Tool (AMT). Far and away the two most powerful tools were Director and AMT. The trouble is, Director is not suitable for very large projects and Apple has quit supporting and selling AMT - which was my favorite. In addition, both Director and AMT have very little "carry-over value," because they are too expensive to expect my students mostly teachers - to buy. To make matters worse, I have to pick an authoring tool in the next week or so to use this fall in an advanced graduate course called "Instructional Design for Multimedia."

Today, two of the top candidates for the best overall authoring tool award are Adobe Acrobat and HTML (HyperText Markup Language), the language of the Web. Both of these approaches create truly cross-platform software that will run equally well on Macs and PCs. If you use a Web browser, such as Netscape or Explorer, chances are you already have the Acrobat reader as a helper application that lets you download and read .pdf (portable document format) files (see Power Tools, May 1998). For about $50 you can purchase the full version of Acrobat, which includes Distiller and Extender -the components that let you begin authoring your own Acrobat documents, complete with hypertext buttons, graphics, and so on. I plan to write a column on Acrobat as soon as I have time to learn more about its ability to handle multimedia.
